title: Species geographical co-occurrence and the effect of Grinnellian and Eltonian niche partitioning: The case of a Neotropical felid assemblage
abstract: Understanding local coexistence and broad-scale species co-occurrence patterns are central questions in ecology and macroecology. Niche theory relates both spatial scales by considering the resources (Eltonian niche) and conditions (Grinnellian niche) used by species and allow us to assess the contribution of these factors for species co-occurrence. Indeed, combining local field data on diet preferences and climatic variables across species distributions can help us to evaluate their co-occurrence while jointly considering resources and conditions on niche partitioning. Here, using information drawn from literature, we evaluated the relationship between geographic, climatic (Grinnellian) and trophic (Eltonian) niche dimensions among five highly sympatric felid species in favoring species co-occurrence at broad spatial scales across the Neotropical region. We obtain potential geographic distributions of species through ecological niche models. Then, we calculated the pairwise species overlaps for each niche dimension and tested for a relationship between each pair of dimensions using Mantel and partial Mantel tests. We found a positive and significant relationship between geographic co-occurrence and climatic overlap. This relationship remained after controlling for trophic overlap. Geographic and trophic overlap, as well as climatic and trophic overlap, did not show significant relationships. We conclude that the high degree of geographic co-occurrence among our studied felid species is favored by climate and that their high degree of trophic overlap is not limiting their co-occurrence pattern.

abstract.text: Understanding local coexistence and broad-scale species co-occurrence patterns are central questions in ecology and macroecology. Niche theory relates both spatial scales by considering the resources (Eltonian niche) and conditions (Grinnellian niche) used by species and allow us to assess the contribution of these factors for species co-occurrence. Indeed, combining local field data on diet preferences and climatic variables across species distributions can help us to evaluate their co-occurrence while jointly considering resources and conditions on niche partitioning. Here, using information drawn from literature, we evaluated the relationship between geographic, climatic (Grinnellian) and trophic (Eltonian) niche dimensions among five highly sympatric felid species in favoring species co-occurrence at broad spatial scales across the Neotropical region. We obtain potential geographic distributions of species through ecological niche models. Then, we calculated the pairwise species overlaps for each niche dimension and tested for a relationship between each pair of dimensions using Mantel and partial Mantel tests. We found a positive and significant relationship between geographic co-occurrence and climatic overlap. This relationship remained after controlling for trophic overlap. Geographic and trophic overlap, as well as climatic and trophic overlap, did not show significant relationships. We conclude that the high degree of geographic co-occurrence among our studied felid species is favored by climate and that their high degree of trophic overlap is not limiting their co-occurrence pattern.

body_text.text: individual geographic distributions of species in particular sites/regions (Gleason, 1926; Ricklefs, 2004) . Thus, explaining such patterns requires understanding the processes that determine species geographical distributions (Gotelli et al., 2009) . These processes include physiological (e.g., tolerance to abiotic conditions), ecological (e.g., biotic interactions), historical (e.g., geologic events) and evolutionary (e.g., speciation dynamics) processes (Gaston, 2003) .

The niche concept, as defined by Hutchinson (1957) as a multidimensional space with axes defined by resources and conditions required for a species to survive, can be used to conceptualize and analyze species coexistence at local spatial scales (Silvertown, 2004) as well as their individual geographical distributions at broad spatial scales (Soberón, 2007) . On the one hand, niche partitioning or differentiation is thought to be important for limiting interspecific competition and thus favoring species coexistence (Schoener, 1974) . On the other hand, both biotic (e.g., resources, interactions) and abiotic (e.g., environmental conditions) factors are important for determining species geographic distributions at local and broad spatial scales, respectively (Soberón, 2007) . Considering these two types of factors, Soberón (2007) defined Eltonian and Grinnellian niches to refer to interactive, resource-related (e.g., dietary) variables at local scales and non-interactive, abiotic (e.g., climatic) variables at broad scales, respectively. In a similar vein, particularly in the context of plant coexistence, these local and broadscale factors have been termed α-niche and β-niche, respectively (Silvertown, Dodd, Gowing, Lawson, & McConway, 2006) . Given our focus on particular aspects (diet and climate) of animal species geographic distributions, hereafter we will refer solely to Eltonian and Grinnellian niches following Soberón (2007) . From this perspective of scale-dependent factors, it is possible to think on species coexistence favored by partitioning of Eltonian and/or Grinnellian niches.

Aspects of the Eltonian niche, such as biotic interactions, are usually considered unimportant in determining species distributions and coexistence at broad spatial scales (Soberón, 2007; Wiens, 2011) . However, biotic factors such as competition and trophic relationships can still be important in determining species distributional limits and overlap (Godsoe, Jankowski, Holt, & Gravel, 2017; Wisz et al., 2013) . Still, evaluating the effect of these biotic factors at broad spatial scales is hindered by the difficulty of obtaining information at such scales (Araújo & Guisan, 2006; Soberón, 2007) . One possibility to overcome this difficulty is to rely on the compilation of local field data from the literature (e.g., diets, Kissling et al., 2014) . Combining this data at local scales with more easily accessible data at broad spatial scales, such as climatic variables describing species geographical distributions (Soberón, 2007) , can help to evaluate species cooccurrence at broad spatial scales while jointly considering Eltonian and Grinnellian niche partitioning.

Niche partitioning mechanisms can be better approximated by considering sympatric and ecologically similar species (Schoener, 1974) . Felidae (Mammalia, Carnivora) species share exceptional morphological and trophic (e.g., hypercarnivorry, mostly specializing in mammalian prey; Macdonald & Loveridge, 2010; Van Valkenburgh, 1991) characteristics as well as environmental preferences (Diniz-Filho et al., 2010) . Therefore, felids represent an ideal system to evaluate species coexistence through both Eltonian and Grinnellian niche partitioning (Hearn et al., 2018) . Several felid studies have shown that diet, activity pattern and behavioral flexibility allow felid species to coexist while avoiding competition (Hayward & Kerley, 2008; Hearn et al., 2018; Migliorini, Peters, Favarini, & Kasper, 2018) . For instance, for Neotropical felid species, the high similarity in diet (Farrell, Roman, & Sunquist, 2000) , habitat use (Nagy-Reis, Nichols, Chiarello, Ribeiro, & Setz, 2017) and geographic overlap (Clavijo & Ramírez, 2009; Sánchez-Cordero et al., 2008) , suggest that such ecological flexibility favors species coexisting through high Eltonian and Grinnellian niche overlap and thus low partitioning.

Here, we aimed to evaluate the relationship between Eltonian and Grinnellian niches in favoring felid species coexistence at broad spatial scales across the Neotropics. More specifically, we evaluated the relationship between geographic, climatic (Grinnellian), and trophic (Eltonian) niche dimensions among five highly sympatric felid species (cougar Puma concolor, jaguar Panthera onca, jaguarundi Herpailurus yagouaroundi, margay Leopardus wiedii and ocelot Leopardus pardalis). These species show the widest geographical distributions as well as the highest degree of overlap among Neotropical felids (Clavijo & Ramírez, 2009) . They also show similarity in their body sizes, with the jaguarundi, margay and ocelot being similarly small (3.3-12 kg) while the cougar and jaguar are similarly large (54-84 kg) (Pacifici et al., 2013) . Available information on their geographic distribution (e.g., point occurrences) and on the climatic variables across the Neotropics, allows characterizing both geographic and climatic (Grinnellian) niche dimensions (Colwell & Rangel, 2009) . In addition, there is considerable information on their particular diets across the Neotropics (Booth-Binczik et al., 2013; Chinchilla, 1997; Moreno, Kays, & Samudio, 2006) , allowing the characterization of at least one aspect of their Eltonian niches; their dietary preferences. Considering the high similarity in diet and habitat use among Neotropical felids (Farrell et al., 2000 ; Nagy-Reis et al., 2017) and the high degree of geographical overlap among our five species (Clavijo & Ramírez, 2009) , we expected that (a) they will present a high degree of climatic overlap, although this will be less pronounced than their observed geographic overlap given that species can co-occur in the same geographic space but use the available climatic conditions differently (Broennimann et al., 2012) . Also, considering that felines are opportunistic predators and obligate carnivores with 80% or more of their diets being meat (Migliorini et al., 2018) and that such diet is highly related to their body sizes (Tucker & Rogers, 2014) , we expected them to (b) present high overlap in their diets. Finally, if diet composition is a limiting factor for the co-occurrence of these species, we expected that (c) the species with greater overlap in their diets will present lower overlap in their geographical distributions.

We focused on five widely distributed and sympatric species of Neotropical felids: cougar Puma concolor, jaguar Panthera onca, jaguarundi Herpailurus yagouaroundi, margay Leopardus wiedii and ocelot Leopardus pardalis. Although we studied only five out of the 12 recognized species of Felidae in the Americas (Sunquist & Sunquist, 2014) , our studied species are the ones that shared most of their geographical distributions with each other and, more importantly, are also the most studied felid species in the region allowing us to obtain information on their dietary preferences.

To describe the geographical distributions of our five species, we first gathered data on their occurrences (point records) from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF; www.gbif.org). To curate the data, we deleted records with taxonomic and georeference errors as well as duplicated ones. Then, to obtain a representation of the species geographical distributions in terms of their extents of occurrence (Gaston, 2003) , we built ecological niche models (ENMs, see below). ENMs allowed us to obtain the potential distributions of each species, considering the relationship between the species occurrence and climate in areas that have been historically accessible for the species as well as in areas of potential access (Barve et al., 2011; Soberón, 2007) . Although extents of occurrence polygons ("range maps") are already available for our species, such as the maps provided by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN; www.iucnredlist.org), we did not consider them appropriate for our question since they focus mainly on the contemporary distribution of species, which is biased by our knowledge on species, including anthropogenic pressures and does not reflect the historical distribution of the species (Faurby et al., 2018) . In addition, such bias is unevenly distributed among species, with the distribution of some species being highly studied and refined (e.g., the jaguar) others are poorly known (e.g., the jaguarundi).

Climatic data was obtained from the version 1 of the climatic layers provided by the WorldClim online database (Hijmans, Cameron, Parra, Jones, & Jarvis, 2005) . Layers had a spatial resolution of 30 arc-seconds (approx. 1 km around the equator). To obtain species potential distributions from ENMs, it is crucial to define the accessible area for each species (M), since this influences the performance and validation of the ENMs (Barve et al., 2011) . To define the M of each species, we used the terrestrial ecoregions of the world at biome resolution (Olson et al., 2001) . In a geographical information system (QGIS development team, 2016), we used the select by interception tool to select each polygon that touch or contain a presence record of a species and then merged the resulting selection into a single polygon representing that species' M.

The ENMs were performed using the MaxEnt algorithm (ver. 3.4.0; Phillips, Dudík, & Schapire, 2017), maintaining the default parametrization except for the "do clamping" and "extrapolate" functions that were turned off to avoid artificial extrapolations on extreme values of the climatic variables (Merow, Smith, & Silander Jr, 2013) . From the original dataset of presence records of each species, a 20% of records were excluded to perform the posterior validation of the model and the 80% remaining were used to calibrate the model. From the jackknife results of a first MaxEnt's model including the 19 bioclimatic variables, we selected a variable subset that included the variables with the greater contribution to the model and the lower degree of correlation (≤ 80%): Bio 2 (mean diurnal range), Bio 3 (isothermality), Bio 4 (temperature seasonality), Bio 15 (precipitation seasonality), Bio 18 (precipitation of warmest quarter) and Bio 19 (precipitation of coldest quarter). Then, we built a second model using this subset of variables.

Based on the fact that presence records have different degrees of uncertainty, we defined a 10% omission rate threshold in training records to binarize the resulting maps. That is, we defined species presence (1) based on the probability value that included 90% of the training records and species absence (0) for all the values below that threshold.

Model validation was carried out using two methods. First, we estimated the area under the curve (AUC) of the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve. Several problems have been associated with this metric (e.g., Lobo, Jiménez-Valverde, & Real, 2008; Peterson, Papes¸, & Soberón, 2008) . Therefore, we applied a second method (partial ROC; Peterson et al., 2008 ) that can give different weights to omission and commission errors. The partial ROC gives us a value of AUC ratio where values close to 1 indicate a poor performance (i.e., the model predictions are similar to the null expectations) and values greater than 1 indicate a good performance (i.e., the model predictions are better than the null expectation). For partial ROC analysis, we used the software "Tool for Partial-ROC V. 1.0." (Barve, 2008) , establishing an omission rate of 5% (i.e., models were evaluated under an established omission threshold).

To gather data on the prey preferences of each felid species, we built a database by conducting an extensive literature search using the keywords "diet," "prey," "consumption," "food" along with the common and scientific name of each felid species in four academic databases: Web of Science (WoS), Scopus, Redalyc and in the National Autonomous University of Mexico (UNAM, Spanish acronym) thesis repository. The UNAM repository was selected in function of the national and international importance of this University in the Neotropics. To complement this database, we further inspected the references of the compiled papers and also included information from the book "El jaguar en el nuevo milenio" (Medellín et al., 2002) .

For this study, we considered only mammalian prey to characterize felids diets. We excluded non-mammal preys in the diet of the felids for three reasons: (a) nonmammal preys are rarely identified at genus or even family level (e.g., Silva-Pereira, Moro-Rios, Bilski, & Passos, 2011), (b) digestion of birds in some felid species has been shown to be very fast (Pires, Widmer, Silva, & Setz, 2011) , thus, hindering their detectability on felid scats and (c) relative importance of non-mammal prey in felid diets is usually considered to be minimal (e.g., Moreno et al., 2006; Silva-Pereira et al., 2011) .

We calculated the degree of geographic overlap between each species pair using the potential distributions obtained from the ENMs. For each species pair (n = 10), the degree of overlap was defined as the proportion of the smallestranged species overlapped by the largest-ranged species (Barraclough & Vogler, 2000) following the next formula:
Geographic overlap = a \ b a

where a \ b corresponds to the shared pixels between "a" (the smallest-ranged species), and "b" (largest-ranged species). We used the pixels from the potential distributions as units to measure the species range sizes and degree of overlap. The degree of overlap varies from 0.0 (no overlap) to 1.0 (complete overlap of the smallestranged species within the largest-ranged species).

To calculate the climatic overlap between species pairs, we used the framework proposed by Broennimann et al. (2012) . This framework is based on an ordination (principal component analysis, PCA) of the climatic space defined by the background area (accessible area, M above) occupied by both species on a pair. This ordination space is gridded into cells with each of these representing a unique vector of climatic conditions present at one or more locations in the geographical space. Then, kernel density functions are applied to calculate the smoothed density of number of occurrences and of available climatic conditions. An occupancy index is then estimated based on these values, which allows an unbiased comparison between areas with different distributions of climatic conditions. Finally, Grinnellian niche overlap is calculated by Schoener's D index based on occupation of climatic space (i.e., density of occurrence corrected by climatic variability) (Broennimann et al., 2012) .
We estimated trophic overlap between species pairs by using Pianka's index (Pianka, 1973) with the following formula:
O jk = P n i p ij p ik ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi P n i p 2 ij P n i p 2 ik s

where O jk is Pianka's index of niche overlap between species j and k, p ij is the proportion of the ith resource in the diet of species j, p ik is the proportion of the ith resource in the diet of species k, and n is the total number of resources (i.e., prey species). Pianka's index ranges from 0 (no common food items in diet) to 1 (total overlap of diets). We calculated the proportion of each resource type through the relative importance of a family in the diet of a felid species, in turn calculated as the quotient of the number of preys belonging to the same family in the diet of one felid species divided by the total number of preys in the same felid's diet.

From the overlap values observed between each pair of species for each niche dimension, geographic, Grinnellian/climatic and Eltonian/trophic, we built similarity matrices where the rows and columns were species and the entries corresponded to the overlap values observed between the corresponding pair of species. Then, we transformed these similarity matrices into dissimilarity matrices by subtracting the similarity value from unity (1-overlap value).

Using the dissimilarity matrices, we tested and compared the correlation between the three niche dimensionsgeographic, Grinnellian/climatic and Eltonian/trophicfocusing on determining the effect of climatic and trophic overlap in favoring or limiting the geographic overlap among species. To do so, we applied Mantel tests to evaluate the correlation between each pair of matrices and partial Mantel tests to evaluate the correlation between Grinnellian/climatic or Eltonian/trophic on geographic dissimilarity among species while controlling for Eltonian/trophic and Grinnellian/climatic dissimilarity, respectively. Although the Mantel, and partial Mantel, test have been subject to strong criticisms (Guillot & Rousset, 2013; Legendre & Fortin, 2010) , these are mainly related to its use in the spatial analysis of genetic data (distances) and the detection of spatial structures/correlation (Legendre, Fortin, & Borcard, 2015) . Indeed, its use concerning dissimilarity matrices (as done here) has been supported and deemed reliable (Diniz-Filho et al., 2013; Legendre et al., 2015) . Particularly in the case of the partial Mantel test, when an explanatory matrix is controlled by another one, thus, having two matrices in the explanatory set, it is possible to consider an alternative known as multiple regression on distance matrices (MRM; Lichstein, 2007) . MRM simultaneously evaluates the effect of several explanatory matrices, describing the individual contribution of these to a response matrix (Lichstein, 2007) . However, MRM has been shown to produce similar results to those of the partial Mantel test (Diniz-Filho et al., 2013) . Indeed, this was our case when we applied MRM to our data (Supporting Information S1), evaluating the influence of Grinnellian/climatic and Eltonian/trophic dissimilarity on geographic dissimilarity among species. Therefore, we present results only for the partial Mantel test to avoid repetition and save space. The statistical significance of the Mantel and partial Mantel Pearson correlation coefficients was tested against chance by permutations (1,000 iterations) in the vegan library (Oksanen, Blanchet, Friendly, Kindt, & Legendre, 2017) in R.

Although we recognized the importance of historical and evolutionary processes in driving species coexistence and thus niche partitioning, here, we focused on ecological processes mainly because our studied species are not each other closest relatives (Nyakatura & Bininda-Emonds, 2012) and previous studies have shown that their geographical distributions have not been as affected by historical changes (geologic and climatic) as those of other felid species in the Neotropics (Arias-Alzate, González-Maya, Arroyo-Cabrales, & Martínez-Meyer, 2017). Nevertheless, to consider the potential effect of shared evolutionary history among our studied species in the statistical tests (i.e., phylogenetic non-independence), all analyses were repeated considering the phylogenetic dissimilarity (distances) among our species. Such distances were extracted from the most recent and comprehensive species-level phylogeny for carnivore mammals (Nyakatura & Bininda-Emonds, 2012) . Mantel tests showed that phylogenetic dissimilarity was not correlated with any of the evaluated niche dissimilarities (geographic, climatic or trophic) (Supporting Information S1), thus, partial Mantel tests and MRM results with and without phylogenetic dissimilarities were similar. Therefore, we present results only for the non-phylogenetic analyses and refer the reader to Supporting Information S1 for results considering phylogenetic relationships among species.

The geographical distribution maps obtained for each species (Figure 1) , generated from the modeling of their ecological niches, indicated that the distributional areas have an average of 9,189,170 ± 1,269,026 km 2 . The species with the smaller area of distribution was the jaguar with 7,148,654 km 2 (Figure 1a) , and the one that occupies the largest area was the cougar with 10,611,427 km 2 (Figure 1b) . The other species had distributional areas of 9,603,255, 9,468,569 and 9,113,949 km 2 corresponding to the ocelot (Figure 1) , the jaguarundi (Figure 1 ) and the margay, respectively (Figure 1) . In general, the ENMs performed well in terms of their AUC, whose average value was 0.84 ± 0.03, and in terms of their AUC ratio, which was on average 1.5 ± 0.15 and was significantly larger than the null expectation for each model (Supporting Information S2).

We found average values of 59% ± 24% of geographic overlap between pairs the five species considered in the present study. The greatest geographic overlap was between the jaguar and the ocelot (83%) and the lowest between the cougar and the margay (24%). In general, the overlap values that did not include the cougar were equal to or greater than 70%. Likewise, the geographic F I G U R E 1 Potential geographic distributions derived from ecological niche models of the five studied felid species, ordered according to their body mass from the largest to the smallest species: (a) jaguar, (b) cougar, (c) ocelot, (d) jaguarundi and (e) margay; in (f) we present the sum of the geographic distributions of the five studied felid species (i.e., richness) overlap of the cougar with the rest of the species was less than or equal to 40% (Table 1) .

We found average values of climatic overlap between species of 43% ± 15%. The greatest climatic overlap occurred between jaguarundi and ocelot (65%), followed by jaguar and jaguarundi (62%), while the lowest was between the cougar and the margay (21%). In general, the lowest values of climatic overlap are observed between the cougar and the rest of the species (cougar and ocelot 23%, cougar and jaguarundi 31% and cougar and jaguar 37%). Only significant climatic overlap values were found between jaguar and margay (52%) and jaguarundi and margay (44%; Table 1 ).

We found a total of 77 publications for 13 countries across the Neotropics, ranging from the southern United States to Argentina, in which data on the diet of at least one of the species of interest were included (see Supporting Information S3 ). In total, 200 different species of prey were found to be consumed by the five felid species. The ocelot was the species with the highest number of reported prey species (n = 129), followed by the jaguar (n = 93) and the cougar (n = 91), whereas the species with the lowest number of prey species recorded in their diet were the jaguarundi (n = 49) and the margay (n = 34).
body_text.section: | Trophic data and Eltonian niche overlap

body_text.text: The greatest trophic overlap occurred between the different combinations of small species (ocelot, jaguarondi and margay) (98% ± 1%) and between the jaguar and the cougar (99%). Conversely, trophic overlap between species such as the cougar and the jaguar with small species presented lower values than in the previous cases (52% ± 10%) (Table 1) . Overall, Eltonian niche overlap was mostly high across all species with eight out of the 10 pairwise comparisons showing overlaps equal or higher than 50%.
body_text.section: | Trophic data and Eltonian niche overlap

body_text.text: We found a positive correlation between the climatic dissimilarity as predictor and the geographical dissimilarity as response (r = .88, p = .02; Table 2; Figure 2a ), indicating that as the climatic dissimilarity increases there is a higher geographic dissimilarity (i.e., less overlap) between species. When we analyzed the relationship between geographic dissimilarity as response and trophic dissimilarity as predictor variable, we found no significant relationship (r = .08, p = .38; Table 2; Figure 2b) . Finally, when we analyzed the relationship between trophic dissimilarity as response and climatic dissimilarity as predictor, we also found no significant relationship between these (r = .08, p = .4; Table 2; Figure 2c ).

When we evaluated the relationship between geographical dissimilarity as response variable and climatic dissimilarity as predictor variable while controlling for trophic dissimilarity, we found a positive and significant relationship indicating that when there is a high degree of climatic dissimilarity there is a high geographic Note: The values above the diagonal with subscript "g" represent the geographic overlap whereas those with subscript "c" represent the climatic overlap; values under the diagonal represent the trophic overlap.

dissimilarity regardless of trophic dissimilarity (r = .88, p = .02, Table 2 ). When we evaluated the relationship between geographical dissimilarity as response variable and the trophic dissimilarity as predictor variable while controlling for climatic dissimilarity, we found a negative but non-significant relationship (r = .02, p = .4; Table 2 ). MRM results confirmed those of the partial Mantel tests, with a significant relationship between geographic dissimilarity and climatic dissimilarity regardless of trophic dissimilarity. Finally, when we evaluated the relationship between trophic dissimilarity and climatic dissimilarity while controlling for geographic dissimilarity, we found a positive but non-significant relationship (r = .01, p = .5; Table 2 ).

Our approach based on the use of relevant biotic information (i.e., compiled from field work), for the analysis of species coexistence at broad spatial scales shows that the geographic overlap between the studied felid species is primarily mediated through their Grinnellian niche similarities regardless of their Eltonian niche similarities. That is, climate was more important than diet in determining geographic coexistence, thus, supporting our first prediction but rejecting our third one. Taken together, our findings suggest low niche partitioning among our studied species, at least on the considered niche dimensions. Indeed, we found that our studied species exhibit a high degree of overlap in their diets, contrary to what would be expected under competitive exclusion (Schoener, 1974) but in agreement with our second prediction according to the opportunistic predatory behavior of Neotropical felids (Moreno et al., 2006) . Finally, we found that our studied felid species exhibit high values of overlap in all three niche dimensions evaluated, ranging from 40% to 70% of average overlap with Eltonian niches (trophic) showing the highest overlap and Grinnellian niches (climatic) showing the lowest overlap, whereas geographic overlap showed intermediate overlap values.

The high degree of geographic overlap observed between the studied felid species, particularly between those of similar body size such as the ocelot, jaguarondi and margay, is striking considering that these species not only co-occur widely among them but they also do so with other felid (Clavijo & Ramírez, 2009) and carnivore species across their entire distributions, which would imply potential competition among these species given their carnivore diets but that is not supported by our findings. In fact, throughout the Neotropics, it is common to find three or more of our studied felid species coexisting locally (e.g., Chinchilla, 1997; Farrell et al., 2000; Konecny, 1989; Nagy-Reis et al., 2017; Rocha-Mendes, Mikich, Quadros, & Pedro, 2010) . Indeed, the high degree of geographic overlap observed in our study seems to be common for felids in several places (Hayward & Kerley, 2008; Hearn et al., 2018; Nagy-Reis et al., 2017) in which, unlike to what is observed for canids, no changes in density have been observed in response to the dominance of species of larger size (Newsome et al., 2017) . Moreover, such high geographic overlap could also be related to biogeographical and historical reasons, given the low species richness of mammalian predators observed in the region (Sandom et al., 2013) and particularly of felid species (Pedersen, Sandel, & Svenning, 2014) , group within which 30% of species have been lost in the Americas during the last tens of thousands of years (Arias-Alzate et al., 2017) . This low richness of predators and the loss of several felid species may allow the extant species to co-occur in places where climatic conditions are favorable and resources are not limiting, considering the reduced number of potential competitors, which may lead to a high degree of trophic overlap and high Grinnellian niche similarity as observed among our studied species.

Grinnellian niche (climatic) overlap observed among our studied species, and its influence on their geographic overlap, may be a result of the climatic and biogeographic history of the Neotropics, allowing species with similar climatic preferences to co-occur (Arias-Alzate et al., 2017; Pedersen et al., 2014; Zurano et al., 2017) . Historical changes in climate can act as a constraint for the distribution of species, with some species expanding or reducing their distributions whereas others becoming extinct, thus, favoring the present co-occurrence of species able to cope with such changes (Arias-Alzate et al., 2017) . In addition, historical changes in climate may favor the use of different climatic conditions by carnivore species, allowing them to exploit different habitat types by developing morphological adaptations that favor coexistence (Zurano et al., 2017) . Our results, however, seem to be more related to an environmental filtering according to what was found by Arias-Alzate et al. (2017) , in which Neotropical carnivore communities are composed of those species that have been able to tolerate the historical changes in climate and whose geographical distributions overlap. The Neotropical region is characterized by a great diversity of mammal species, many of which can be considered as potential prey for carnivores (Sandom et al., 2013) . However, the region is also surprisingly characterized by a poor representation of carnivorous mammals (Sandom et al., 2013 ). If we consider the high richness of potential preys and the poor richness of carnivorous mammals together with the fact that different carnivore species have different metabolic requirements according to their body sizes (Tucker & Rogers, 2014) , a high degree of trophic overlap would not be expected. However, a high degree of overlap was observed in the diets of all of our studied species, even between species with large differences in their body size (e.g., between jaguar and margay). This can be taken as evidence of the opportunistic behavior and diet flexibility previously described for several Neotropical felid species (Moreno et al., 2006; Rabinowitz & Nottingham Jr, 1986) and is consistent with the observed changes in the diet of some felid species as a response to the changes in composition of the felid assemblage (Moreno et al., 2006) . The high trophic overlap exhibited by our studied species could also explain the lack of relationship between the Eltonian niche overlap and the geographic overlap among species. Indeed, while the pairwise species comparisons for both geographic and Grinnellian niche overlaps presented similar values (i.e., the same species pair showed high/ low overlap), the Eltonian niche overlap was mostly high across all species (>50%), thus, showing no ample variation in this niche dimension that could be significantly related to the pairwise variation observed in the other two dimensions.

Authors like Davies, Meiri, Barraclough, and Gittleman (2007) , analyzing all carnivores, showed that greater similarity in dentition, and thus diet, is related to lower spatial co-occurrence suggesting that competition may be influencing the assembly of carnivore communities. However, in later works such as those of Arias-Alzate et al. (2017), Villalobos, Olalla-Tárraga, Cianciaruso, Rangel, and Diniz-Filho (2017) and Zurano et al. (2017) , climatic and historical factors were suggested as the main causes for the co-occurrence patterns among mammals in general (Villalobos et al., 2017) , Neotropical canid species (Zurano et al., 2017) and F I G U R E 2 Relationship between the three niche dimensions.

(a) Climatic dissimilarity and geographic dissimilarity, (b) trophic dissimilarity and geographic dissimilarity and (c) climatic dissimilarity and trophic dissimilarity. For illustrative purposes, the continuous line in (a) represents the linear relationship between the variables according to an ordinary least squares model (OLS) American carnivores, particularly felid species (Arias-Alzate et al., 2017). Our results considering both niche dimensions, diet and climate, in the evaluation of species cooccurrence, seem to agree with the results of Arias-Alzate et al. 2017, Villalobos et al. (2017) and Zurano et al. (2017) , since the high degree of trophic overlap found in our study is not related to the observed climatic or geographic overlap whereas the geographic overlap is highly related to the climatic overlap observed between the studied felid species even when trophic overlap was taken into account.

Our results suggest that climate, and not diet, is the main driver of the geographic overlap observed among the studied felid species. If climate acts as a filter at the regional level for Neotropical carnivore species, as was previously observed by Arias-Alzate et al. 2017, it is possible to think that local carnivore communities are structured by the relationship between local climatic conditions and the climatic tolerances of carnivore species that can occur in a certain place. If this is true, the high trophic overlap observed in our results at the continental scale and their agreement with findings from local scale studies (e.g., Bianchi, Rosa, Gatti, & Mendes, 2011; Chinchilla, 1997; Migliorini et al., 2018; Wang, 2002) , may result from the number and body size of felid species present at each particular locality, the number of potential preys (Sandom et al., 2013) , the size of these potential prey and their relationship with the predator size in terms of the energetic relevance of the prey (Tucker & Rogers, 2014) . That is, if the climatic conditions in a particular place allow a great amount of felid species of similar size to co-occur, a common pattern observed across the Neotropical region (Clavijo & Ramírez, 2009) , these species may consume similar-sized prey to satisfy their energetic requirements (Tucker & Rogers, 2014) , which can lead to high local overlap in their diets and this pattern can scale up to the regional level, consistent with our results.

The inclusion of biotic information compiled from field work is crucial to determine the relative importance of Eltonian (biotic) and Grinnellian (abiotic) niche dimensions in the distribution of species at fine-spatial scales (Soberón, 2007) as well as in the assembly of communities even at broad spatial scales (Godsoe et al., 2017; Gotelli et al., 2010) , particularly in those groups where competition is suggested to be strong such as in carnivores (Pedersen et al., 2014; Zurano et al., 2017) . Our work suggests that climatic factors seem to be the main limiting factor on the broad-scale community assembly of the studied felid assemblage, and our results further suggest that aspects such as trophic overlap are not limiting felid co-occurrence at the continental scale. This is consistent with previous claims that local scale processes do not scale up to determine species' coexistence and diversity patterns at broad spatial scales (Fine, 2015; Soberón, 2007) .

We thank Salvador Mandujano, Enrique Martínez-Meyer, Pilar Rodríguez, Alberto González-Romero, Andrés Lira-Noriega and Julián Velasco for insightful comments on the manuscript.
